 Thank you for sharing your experience and your opinion. There is nothing about pregnancy that inherently 'sucks.' There are many potential consequences of pregnancy, some of which you describe quite vividly above. What you make those consequences mean to you is completely up to you. I know many individuals whose experience and attitude toward pregnancy (including, of course, several women who have given birth) is completely different than yours. I even know a few women who have chosen to give their babies up for adoption who treasured the experience of being pregnant with a baby they weren't going to raise. Yes, pregnancy has consequences that can be challenging. Yes, some people have the attitude that pregnancy 'sucks.' But that is not the only attitude that is possible, nor the only attitude that is chosen.

 You were joking, but you were also arguing that pregnancy is uniformly awful and something men are not missing out on. While I will admit never wanting to experience pregnancy (except maybe for having a little person growing inside me--the feeling must be a trip!), I do envy the deep love that people often develop for their mothers that is less commonly seen toward fathers, and I suspect that the deeper love begins in the womb. 
 
 I do think it is unfair that society puts a great deal of responsibility on men for raising their children, but denies them any real power over whether a baby is born or not. You can hardly blame the guy who minimizes the support he gives to a child he was against having in the first place. And it even seems wrong for a woman to say, "Surprise, I'm pregnant, and I'm keeping the baby, and you'll have no part in it." The guy may be able to get a court to order visitation rights, but there is no way the man can be deeply involved in the life of his child without the mother agreeing. 
 
 Of course, you can argue that the man is to blame for his predicament; if he doesn't want to lose control over whether babies will be born or aborted, then don't have sex with the woman. This is a valid point, but the plain fact is that he and the woman both had a say over having sex, but only the woman has say about whether she will abort the baby or not. Any fair person will say that it is wrong for a man to have no say in the life of his own child.

Consider that your use of the word 'endure' implies a less than positive value is assigned to pregnancy.  It's all a matter of perspective.

 
 Let me guess...you're a guy. The "joys of pregnancy"? I am currently about 8 months pregnant. Although there are fun things about pregnancy (feeling the fetus move, hearing the heartbeat, seeing the ultrasound) there are other things that aren't so joyful. Such as the high blood pressure I've been having. Having to get up every 20 minutes to pee in the middle of the night. Having my feet swell. Not being able to eat certain things (like the feta cheese I can't eat because of the risk of Listeriosis) or take certain things (like the medication I used to take for my migraines). Not being able to sleep. Being irritable to everyone I love because of hormones. Having varicose veins in very uncomfortable areas. Not being able to tie my own shoes or shave my legs. The AMAZING amount of stretch marks all over my belly. Backache. Every single ligament in my belly aching where the uterus attaches. Heartburn. Constipation. Not being able to see my feet.
 Yeah, it's all just so joyful. emoticon_rolleyes And yet, even though I'm prochoice, I still CHOSE to carry to term.

 Yeah, it's all just so joyful. emoticon_rolleyes And yet, even though I'm prochoice, I still CHOSE to carry to term.

 
 As a father who has awestruckenly witnessed the birth of all three of my kids "up close and personally", I can guarantee you that once the baby arrives, you forget all about the negatives associated with pregnancy. It's truly a miracle and one that should NEVER be minimized IMO.
 Good luck on the rest of your pregnancy and I wish you a healthy, happy baby and many years of good memories. Take lots of pictures, all of the time. They grow up in the blink of an eye. (My youngest will be 18 in two weeks and I can remember the day she was born as if it was yesterday.)
 God bless you. :)

 if there is someone else wanting to adopt the child. No type of "sign off"

 I could be totally wrong because its difficult to find accurate info on the web.

Then you must know a lot of nefarious characters. My wife doesn't run around my neighborhood paranoid over being raped and I doubt that many others on this board do, either. So, it's logical to assume that you must live in a rough area or have questionable associations.
 
 
 Hum, let's see. You married an abuser, were raped and you let your hormones get the better of you on occasion, but you don't trust men like me.
 Men like me........I'm 48, have been married to the same woman for 26 years, never cheated on her, never raised a hand to her in anger, have three adult children, all top in their academic classes, moral and respectful of others.
 Yep, you shouldn't trust men like me. emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 It appears that your moral compass is broken. I'm not the enemy. 
 I truly feel sorry for you. You are so filled with hatred towards men that you have blinded yourself to the fact that not all men are bad and I fear that you wouldn't be able to recognize a good man if you encountered one. What kind of atmosphere is that to raise a son in? Have you imprinted your paranoia onto your son? It's important for him to know what is proper male behavior by having a good example. Do you, at least, have ONE male role model for him to emmulate?
 
 Don't feel the need to respond to my above "soapbox session" in this forum unless you're comfortable doing so. I would rather that you think about what I wrote than worry about a good comeback.

 
 First of all, I need to point out to you that you are practicing revictimization here. It's the idea that the victim did something to deserve an attack (location, acquaintances, etc.). The truth about rape is that one in three woman will be raped. One third of us - and the attacker is usually someone the victim knows and trusts. I assure you, I am not more worried about rape than reality dictates.
 
 Secondly, I don't hate men. That's ridiculous. The two people I trust most in the world are my mother and my son's male mentor/father. One of my two best friends is a guy. My social circle revolves around the music scene - which is a whole lotta guys. I love guys. They are cute as heck and taste just like chicken. 
 
 There is no question that my negative experiences have fueled my desire to be independent. My son is ten. I am 35. I have a roaming spirit. I honest injun don't want more kids. I don't want to get married, start another family and live a quiet life in the burbs. When my son goes to college I plan to sell my house, move to Toronto and focus more on music. That isn't me hating men, that's just what I want. So my life doesn't have a lot of romance and when it does, it's pretty easy on the head - that is by choice, not a sad product of my life. 
 
 Personal freedom, independence and choice are absolutely critical to me. It's not that I don't trust you as an individual, I don't trust you to see that, to even understand that. So based on that, and the course I was planning for my future, I decided to get my tubes tied.
 
 You have yet to address what I have brought up twice. Why do conservative men have a problem with me having done this? It was an informed, adult choice. I hurt nobody. Is there some underlying idea that I am supposed to keep my bodily resources available for men? Max once asked me what if I did meet the right guy. I actually think that would be fabulous, but considering what I want in life, the right guy for me won't want children (or young children anyway).
JPSartre12

First of all, I need to point out to you that you are practicing revictimization here. It's the idea that the victim did something to deserve an attack (location, acquaintances, etc.). The truth about rape is that one in three woman will be raped. One third of us - and the attacker is usually someone the victim knows and trusts. I assure you, I am not more worried about rape than reality dictates.

 I guess my words may have come off that way, but it wasn't my intent. I don't believe that rape is 100% random, however, but that's a topic for another thread.
 

 Secondly, I don't hate men. That's ridiculous. The two people I trust most in the world are my mother and my son's male mentor/father. One of my two best friends is a guy. My social circle revolves around the music scene - which is a whole lotta guys. I love guys. They are cute as heck and taste just like chicken. 

 From your previous posts about not ever trusting men and never wanting to lose control, etc., it surely sounded like you had a "bad taste" for the male population. 
 

 There is no question that my negative experiences have fueled my desire to be independent. My son is ten. I am 35. I have a roaming spirit. I honest injun don't want more kids. I don't want to get married, start another family and live a quiet life in the burbs. When my son goes to college I plan to sell my house, move to Toronto and focus more on music. That isn't me hating men, that's just what I want. So my life doesn't have a lot of romance and when it does, it's pretty easy on the head - that is by choice, not a sad product of my life. 

 Fear of intimacy really isn't a choice, but I'll accept that you don't want any encumberances in your life after your son is grown. And not everyone living in "the burbs" lives a quiet life, trust me. My son and I spend a lot of our free time drag racing and working on cars and my neighbors know it. :) 
 

 Personal freedom, independence and choice are absolutely critical to me. It's not that I don't trust you as an individual, I don't trust you to see that, to even understand that. So based on that, and the course I was planning for my future, I decided to get my tubes tied.

 Well, I admire independence and have two daughters that I've stressed it with. I don't want either of them to be dependent on another person, either. But there's a difference between dependence and inter-dependence. Inter-dependence can be a symbiotic relationship that is stronger than the sum of its parts. That's the kind of relationship that my wife and I have. We fully realized the strength of our relationship when she was diagnosed with cancer almost exactly a year ago and our relationship is stronger than ever. 
 

 You have yet to address what I have brought up twice. Why do conservative men have a problem with me having done this? It was an informed, adult choice. I hurt nobody. Is there some underlying idea that I am supposed to keep my bodily resources available for men? Max once asked me what if I did meet the right guy. I actually think that would be fabulous, but considering what I want in life, the right guy for me won't want children (or young children anyway).

 
 I guess I didn't answer your question about Conservative men because I was attempting to draw out more information on why you made that particular choice, given that I thought you stated that you had sworn off men. But, that was my mistaken interpretation. I don't have a problem with you not wanting any more kids and think that getting your tubes tied is a reasonable way to prevent an accidental pregnancy. I know lots of Conservative guys who wouldn't have a problem with you taking personal responsibility that way, either, so I was puzzled by your assertion to the contrary. 
 In general, I think that you'll find that Conservative men treat women with more respect than the average man and certainly better than rock stars treat their groupies. :)
jitobear

I guess my words may have come off that way, but it wasn't my intent. I don't believe that rape is 100% random, however, but that's a topic for another thread.

 
 Random - no, I agree with that.
 
 
From your previous posts about not ever trusting men and never wanting to lose control, etc., it surely sounded like you had a "bad taste" for the male population.
 
 
 That's not entirely untrue. My past experiences certainly have contributed to the decisions I make today. But I don't hate men.
 
 
Fear of intimacy really isn't a choice, but I'll accept that you don't want any encumberances in your life after your son is grown. And not everyone living in "the burbs" lives a quiet life, trust me. My son and I spend a lot of our free time drag racing and working on cars and my neighbors know it. :) 

 
 Oh - I know noisy suburbanites, but I am basically saying I am not interested in settling down.
 
 
Well, I admire independence and have two daughters that I've stressed it with. I don't want either of them to be dependent on another person, either. But there's a difference between dependence and inter-dependence. Inter-dependence can be a symbiotic relationship that is stronger than the sum of its parts. That's the kind of relationship that my wife and I have. We fully realized the strength of our relationship when she was diagnosed with cancer almost exactly a year ago and our relationship is stronger than ever. 

 
 I think that is totally true - but I am 35, jaded, and getting set in my ways. It would take one hell of a felxible guy to snare me. And I certainly don't want to waste time mooning for it as if life weren't worth living without it. I know some women (and some men) who can't be single - they will stay with anyone over being alone. I don't get that.
 
 
I guess I didn't answer your question about Conservative men because I was attempting to draw out more information on why you made that particular choice, given that I thought you stated that you had sworn off men. I know lots of Conservative guys who wouldn't have a problem with you taking personal responsibility that way, either, so I was puzzled by your assertion to the contrary. 

 
 I asked it because all the conservative men I have told resisted - reacted negatively to the fact that I had (except my cousin).
 
 
In general, I think that you'll find that Conservative men treat women with more respect than the average man and certainly better than rock stars treat their groupies. :)

 
 I have had conservatives and liberals treat me well - and treat me poorly.
 
 And I'm not a groupie, I'm a bass player! emoticon_xagree 
 
 
 Plus, these local rockers are hardly*rock stars*, even if they seem to think otherwise. emoticon_cool

......

 I didn't mean to suggest that you were a groupie, only that rock stars aren't known for their respect for women. 
 A bass player, eh? What kind of music do you play? My son's a heavy metal lead guitarist. I keep telling him that he should form a band. :)
